topics: Personal Financial Planning and Taxation Winter 2025
AFM 321
Email: kaishu.wu@uwaterloo.ca
AFM 321:
This course integrates financial planning and taxes for individuals.
It connects elements of planning, saving, spending, and reporting to budgeting and tax implications, as they evolve over an individual's lifetime.
View requirements for AFM 321
AFM 321 helps students develop a do-it-yourself (DIY) individual financial planning and tax mindset.
Students will learn how to prepare and assess a basic financial plan for themselves, centered around the budget, across various life stages.
Within each area of planning, saving, spending, and reporting, students will develop appreciation of important financial and tax considerations that will set them up for financial success.
Prepare a financial plan and budget for various life stages using fore core elements (planning, saving, spending, and reporting)
2. Analyze and recommend a financial plan/budget for various life stages
3. Integrate tax implications and analysis within your plan/budget and each life stage
4. Use data and analytical techniques to evaluate comparable investments
3 individual budget and financial planning assignments 37%
TopHat knowledge and reflection questions & Module practice problems 13%

Individually or in groups, students will complete mini-cases requiring them to prepare a budget and all related documentation, including tax implications, related to planning, saving, spending, and reporting.

Students will write a comprehensive final exam that builds on the previous budget and financial planning assignments and will require them to prepare or analyze a budget/financial plan, related schedules, and consider tax calculations and implications.
The assignment will require a written report detailing the comparison and conclusions reached, as well as collection and analysis of data and a visualization of certain findings.
To be awarded a grade for these components, you must enroll in TopHat using your UW username-specific email (no alias UW email address, or non-UW email address).
GenAI use is not permitted for these problems.
The instructor is a facilitator of the knowledge and discussion.
9-10 if you attended classes throughout the term, and participated meaningfully in the discussion several times each week consistently throughout the term.

FMO theory, organometallics, and transition metal-catalyzed C-C bond formation.
Chemistry 360 builds on the concepts and chemistry taught in CHEM 264 and CHEM 265.
If you want to do well in CHEM 360, you should re-familiarize yourself with some of the material in your introductory organic chemistry courses.
More specifically, CHEM 360 will familiarize students with some of the modern synthetic methods for the formation of carbon-carbon sigma bonds in organic compounds.

An array of anionic, cationic, pericyclic, and organometallic methods will be introduced as part of three general sections, and the factors governing the mechanistic, stereochemical and regiochemical course of these processes will be presented and discussed as appropriate.

Section 1 will cover enols and enolates, condensations and a-substitutions of carbonyl compounds (acid- and base-catalyzed), and conjugate addition to a,b-unsaturated carbonyl compounds (acid- and base-catalyzed).

Section 2  will cover pericyclic reactions (cycloadditions under thermal and photochemical conditions), with an emphasis on how an appreciation of frontier molecular orbitals allows for prediction of the reactivity of the systems (thermal and photochemical conditions), as well as relative reaction rates, regiochemistry and stereochemistry.
Section 3  will present transition-metal catalysis and organometallic reactions, with a particular emphasis on Pd-catalyzed cross-coupling reactions.
1) To learn to use curve arrow formalism to “push” pairs of electrons in writing resonance forms and in sketching electron flow in chemical reactions.
To be able to use the understanding of reactions mechanisms to predict the outcome of these chemical reactions (mechanistic reasoning to interpret pattern of reactivity).

4) To be able to identify intermediates versus transition states in an energy diagram for all fundamental condensation reactions and be able to determine the difference between kinetically and thermodynamically controlled reactions, identify equilibrium and reaction rates, and relate to the energy of the transitions state, starting material, and final products.
7) To be able to identify neutral cyclic transitions states, involving bond-forming and bond-breaking events, in cycloaddition reactions, under thermal and photochemical conditions.

To be able to use frontier molecular orbitals (FMO’s) to predict the reactivity of cycloadditions under thermal and photochemical conditions, as well as relative reaction rates, regiochemistry and stereochemistry (Endo rule).

11) To be able to generate catalytic cycles for common cross-coupling reactions, namely Suzuki, Stille, Heck, Sonogashira, and Buchwald-Hartwig (Buchwald-Hartwig amination), as well as variations involving carbon monoxide.

Semidefinite Optimization Spring 2023
Optimization over convex sets described as the intersection of the set of symmetric, positive semidefinite matrices with affine spaces.
Theoretical and practical consequences of these formulations.
Duality theory and algorithms.
Optimization over convex sets described as the intersections of the set of symmetric, positive semidefinite matrices with affine spaces.
Formulations of problems from combinatorial optimization, graph theory, number theory, probability and statistics, engineering design and control theory.
Theoretical and practical consequences of these formulations.
Duality theory and algorithms.

Topics Include: Optimization over convex sets described as the intersection of the set of symmetric, positive semideﬁnite matrices with aﬃne spaces: Semideﬁnite optimization vastly generalizes linear programming where variable vectors may be replaced with matrix variables and, in addition to linear equations and inequalities, one may utilize constraints requiring some of the matrix variables to be symmetric and positive semideﬁnite.
duality theory for semideﬁnite optimization,

algorithms for semideﬁnite optimization: ellipsoid method, ﬁrst‐order methods and primal‐dual interior‐point methods for semideﬁnite optimization, and approximation algorithms based on semideﬁnite optimization,

formulations of problems from combinatorial optimization, graph theory, number theory, probability and statistics, complexity analysis of algorithms, engineering design and control theory, theoretical and practical consequences of these formulations,
Polyhedral and Semidefinite Programming Methods in Combinatorial Optimization
The Mathematics of Public-Key Cryptography Fall 2024
An in-depth study of public-key cryptography.
Public-key encryption, digital signatures, key establishment, elliptic curve cryptography, post-quantum cryptography.

An in-depth study of public-key cryptography, including: number-theoretic problems - prime generation, integer factorization, discrete logarithms; public-key encryption; digital signatures; key establishment; elliptic curve cryptography; post-quantum cryptography; and security proofs.
An in-depth study of public-key cryptography and number-theoretic problems related to the efficient and secure use of public-key cryptographic schemes.
Algorithmic number theory: Primality testing, integer factorization problem, discrete logarithm problem, elliptic curve discrete logarithm problem.
Additional topics: Pairing-based cryptography, post-quantum cryptography.
An Introduction to Mathematical Cryptography (2nd ed.), Hoffstein, Pipher, and Silverman.

A broad introduction to modern cryptography, highlighting the tools and techniques used to secure internet and messaging applications.
It is one of the core technologies for securing the emerging information infrastructure.
This course is a comprehensive introduction to modern cryptography that is aimed primarily at those interested in applications.
In the area of public-key cryptography, topics will include an overview of specific systems (Diffie–Hellman, RSA, DSA, etc.) and a few advanced protocols.
The security of these schemes and the use of public-key techniques for generating digital signatures will be described.
Linear and differential cryptanalysis of ciphers.
Define the main information security goals of confidentiality, integrity, authentication, and availability
Explain the intended security properties of each cryptographic primitive and analyze relationships between security properties
Explain mathematical techniques underlying standardized cryptographic algorithms
Identify flaws in uses of cryptographic algorithms
Determine which cryptographic algorithms can be used and combined to build systems with desired functionality and security
Understand and contextualize the cryptography and security around them in daily life

Introduction to Legal Studies Winter 2025
Your instructor checks email and the Ask the Instructor discussion topic frequently and will make every effort to reply to your questions within 24–48 hours, Monday to Friday.
An introduction to the study of law, its structure, and legal institutions from a cross-cultural and historical perspective.
This interdisciplinary course examines the origins of legal systems and their impact on society.
Included is an analysis of the diverse historical, political, economic, and cultural conditions under which law arises and functions within society.
This interdisciplinary course examines the origins of modern legal systems and legal thinking, to consider the impact of law on society, and society on law.

We will do this by exploring the historical, political, economic, and cultural context under which law arises and functions within modern Western society, and its effect on people, institutions, diversity and life.
Demonstrate familiarity with key terms, debates, and theoretical approaches in the field of legal studies.
Identify and analyse popular and scholarly conceptions of law, and the roles law plays in society.

Introduction to Differential Equations Winter 2025
Solving linear differential equations: first- and second-order scalar equations and first-order vector equations.
The main purpose of the course is to explore how first and second order differential equations (DEs) are used to model physical systems and predict their behaviour.
first order linear DE models of compartment problems, atomic decay, and bodies in motion;
first order separable DE models of population growth;
a first order exact DE model of the electric dipole;
second order linear DE models for oscillatory systems such as mass-spring-damper systems and electrical circuits;
second order nonlinear DE models for suspended cables and rocket motion;
linear vector DE models of multiple compartment problems and species interactions.
Both analytical solution techniques and qualitative methods (direction field analysis, dimensional analysis, and phase portraits) will be presented as ways to gain information about system behaviour.
We will investigate conditions for existence, uniqueness, and continuity of solutions of both first and second order initial value problems, and for systems in the plane.
Maple will be used to generate numerical and graphical solutions, to illustrate concepts graphically, and to explore model behaviour.
increase your comprehension of some of the many ways that differential equations can help us understand the real world;
develop your ability to understand a mathematical model for a specific situation;
explore analytical and qualitative solution methods for first and second order differential equations, and the use of Maple; and
Please choose only one of the two options below.
